# Introduction

This guide will walk you through installing the Photo Metadata Editor application. We'll cover multiple methods:

1. **GUI Installer** (Recommended) - Graphical installer with progress tracking
2. **Command Line** - One command for advanced users
3. **Manual Installation** - For those who want more control

Choose the method that works best for you!

---

# Method 1: GUI Installer (Recommended)

The GUI installer provides a friendly graphical interface for installation and updates.

## macOS, Linux, and Unix Systems

### Step 1: Open Terminal

:::{.callout-note}
The Terminal is a program that lets you type commands to your system.
:::

**macOS:**
1. Press **Command (âŒ˜) + Space** on your keyboard
2. This opens Spotlight Search
3. Type: `terminal`
4. Press **Enter** when you see the Terminal app highlighted

**Linux:**
Open any terminal emulator (Ctrl+Alt+T on most systems)

### Step 2: Copy and Run the GUI Installer

Copy this command:

```bash
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/michael6gledhill/Photo_Metadata_App_By_Gledhill/main/install_gui.sh | bash
```

Paste it into your terminal and press **Enter**.

:::{.callout-tip}
## What happens next?
- The script checks for requirements (Git, Python 3)
- Downloads the application
- Launches a **graphical installer window**
- Shows progress as it installs
- Displays logs and status updates in real-time
:::

A graphical installer window will appear showing the installation progress. Just watch as it completes!

# Method 3: Manual Installation

This method gives you more control over each step of the installation process.

## Prerequisites

Before we begin, make sure you have:

- macOS 10.15 (Catalina) or later
- At least 500 MB of free disk space
- Administrator access to your Mac

## Step 1: Open Terminal

1. Press **Command (âŒ˜) + Space**
2. Type: `terminal`
3. Press **Enter**

## Step 2: Install Homebrew (if needed)

Homebrew is a package manager that makes installing software easier.

**Check if you have it:**
```bash
brew --version
```

If you see a version number, skip to Step 3.

**If not, install it:**
```bash
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
```

Follow the on-screen instructions. You may need to enter your Mac password.

## Step 3: Install Git and Python

**Install Git:**
```bash
brew install git
```

**Install Python 3:**
```bash
brew install python@3
```

**Verify installations:**
```bash
git --version
python3 --version
```

You should see version numbers for both.

## Step 4: Choose Your Installation Location

Decide where you want to download the app files. We recommend your home directory:

```bash
cd ~
mkdir -p App
cd App
```

:::{.callout-note}
## What these commands do:
- `cd ~` - Go to your home folder
- `mkdir -p App` - Create a folder called "App"
- `cd App` - Go into that folder
:::

## Step 5: Clone the Repository

**If this is your first time installing:**
```bash
git clone https://github.com/michael6gledhill/Photo_Metadata_App_By_Gledhill.git
```

**If you already installed before and want to update:**
```bash
cd Photo_Metadata_App_By_Gledhill
git pull
```

## Step 6: Navigate to the Project

```bash
cd Photo_Metadata_App_By_Gledhill
```

You should now be inside the project folder.

## Step 7: Install Python Dependencies

First, upgrade pip (Python's package installer):
```bash
python3 -m pip install --upgrade pip
```

Then install the required packages:
```bash
python3 -m pip install -r requirements.txt
```

This installs:
- **PySide6** - GUI framework
- **Pillow** - Image processing
- **piexif** - Metadata handling

## Step 8: Install py2app

py2app is the tool that converts Python scripts into Mac applications:

```bash
python3 -m pip install py2app
```

## Step 9: Build the Application

Now we'll build the actual .app file:

```bash
python3 setup.py py2app
```

:::{.callout-note}
## Build Time
This may take 2-5 minutes. You'll see lots of messages - this is normal!
:::

When complete, you'll see:
```
done running py2app
```

The app is now built in the `dist` folder!

## Step 10: Move to Applications Folder

**Remove old version (if exists):**
```bash
rm -rf "/Applications/Photo Metadata Editor.app"
```

**Copy the new version:**
```bash
cp -R "dist/Photo Metadata Editor.app" /Applications/
```

## Step 11: Launch the App

You can now:

**Option A - From Terminal:**
```bash
open "/Applications/Photo Metadata Editor.app"
```

**Option B - From Finder:**
1. Open **Finder**
2. Go to **Applications**
3. Find **Photo Metadata Editor**
4. Double-click to open

:::{.callout-warning}
## First Launch Security
If you get a security warning, right-click the app, choose **Open**, then click **Open** again.
:::

# Troubleshooting

## Command Not Found Errors

If you get `command not found` errors:

**For brew:**
```bash
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
```

**For python3:**
```bash
brew install python@3
```

**For git:**
```bash
brew install git
```

## Permission Denied Errors

If you get permission errors during installation:

```bash
sudo chown -R $(whoami) ~/App
```

Then try the installation again.

## Build Fails

If `python3 setup.py py2app` fails:

**Clean previous builds:**
```bash
rm -rf build dist
python3 setup.py py2app
```

**Check Python version:**
```bash
python3 --version
```

You need Python 3.8 or later.

## App Won't Open

**Error: "App is damaged"**

This happens with unsigned apps. Fix it:
```bash
xattr -cr "/Applications/Photo Metadata Editor.app"
```

**Error: "Unidentified developer"**

1. Right-click the app
2. Click **Open**
3. Click **Open** in the dialog

## Dependencies Not Found

If the app opens but says packages are missing:

```bash
cd ~/App/Photo_Metadata_App_By_Gledhill
python3 -m pip install -r requirements.txt --force-reinstall
python3 setup.py py2app
cp -R "dist/Photo Metadata Editor.app" /Applications/
```

# Updating the App

To get the latest version:

## Automatic Method

Just run the install command again:
```bash
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/michael6gledhill/Photo_Metadata_App_By_Gledhill/main/Install.sh | bash
```

## Manual Method

```bash
cd ~/App/Photo_Metadata_App_By_Gledhill
git pull
python3 -m pip install -r requirements.txt --upgrade
python3 setup.py py2app
rm -rf "/Applications/Photo Metadata Editor.app"
cp -R "dist/Photo Metadata Editor.app" /Applications/
```

# Updating the App

The Photo Metadata Editor includes built-in update checking!

## Automatic Updates

When you launch the app, it automatically checks for updates in the background. If an update is available:

1. A button in the toolbar will show **âœ¨ Update Available (version)**
2. Click the button to install the update
3. The app will close and restart automatically with the latest version

## Manual Update Check

You can also manually check for updates:

1. Click the **ðŸ”„ Check for Updates** button in the toolbar
2. The app will check for the latest version
3. If an update is available, it will appear in the toolbar

## Update Process

When you click to install an update:

1. The latest code is downloaded from GitHub
2. Dependencies are updated
3. The app closes
4. A new instance with the latest version starts automatically
